questions.text: A 78-year-old man presents with exertional dyspnea. Shortness of breath has been occurring for several months. It is slowly getting worse . He now feels chest pain and light-headed on exertion as well. O/E- Respiratory rate: 12 breaths/minute; BP: 108/72 mm Hg; Pulse: 64 beats/minute; Past medical history-Hypertension, Hyperlipidemia. Cardiovascular: systolic murmur, crescendo-decrescendo heard best in the second right intercostal area. What is the cause of these clinical findings
questions.correct_answer: A. Aortic stenosis

questions.text: A 75-year-old male c/o dyspnea on exertion and had an episode of syncope. O/E parvus et tardus pulse was noted. A systolic murmur at first aortic area radiating to carotids was auscultable. Chest x-ray: normal cardiac shadow, clear lung fields, ECG: left ventricular hypertrophy, Echocardiogram: aortic stenosis with valve area 0.8 cm2 .Which is best treatment now for this patient?
questions.correct_answer: D. Replace with bioprosthetic valve

questions.text: The patient in previous clinical vignette patient refuses to undergo valve replacement surgery. He comes back a few months later. His exercise tolerance has decreased, and he becomes dyspneic even walking across his own living room. He had two more episodes of syncope. He is now ready for valve replacement. What test should you do prior to surgery?
questions.correct_answer: D. Cardiac catheterization

questions.text: A 55 year old male known case of bicuspid aortic valve presented with complaints of chest pain for 3 years, syncope on exercise for last one year and dyspnea for last 3 months. On examination- Pulsus parvus et tardus noted on pulse examination. On auscultation- ejection systolic murmur found at aortic area,LVS3 heard along with LVS4 at apex. A diagnosis of severe AS was made. Which clinical feature will be worst prognostic marker in the patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Dyspnea

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to OPD with increasing shortness of breath and palpitations over the last several months. She also complaint of hemoptysis. She has no fever. Past medical history - rheumatic fever as a child. On examination-Cardiovascular: loud S1 present, there is a high pitch heart sound in diastole just after S2 followed by mid diastolic rumbling murmur apex. What is the cause of this presentation?
questions.correct_answer: A. Mitral stenosis

questions.text: A 24 year old male presented with dyspnea and palpitations. On examination there is loud S1 and mid diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation. Apex beat is tapping in nature. ECG showed left atrial enlargement and chest x ray showing straightening of left heart border. A diagnosis of mitral stenosis is made. What is the basis of the loud S1 in this clinical scenario?

options.label: C
options.text: The mitral valve is still open when LV pressure becomes high.

questions.correct_answer: C. The mitral valve is still open when LV pressure becomes high.

questions.text: A 32 year old patient with known case of RHD with mitral stenosis for 10 years presented to emergency with hemoptysis. On examination BP is 90/60 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, chest is clear, CVS-mid diastolic murmur at apex. Chest x ray shows left atrial enlargement without any parenchymal lesion. What is the causes of hemoptysis in the patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Pulmonary hypertension

questions.text: A 28 year old female complaint of progressively short of breath. Although dyspnea used to occur only with significant exertion, it is now interfering with the patient’s ability to walk up stairs. She occasionally has palpitations. There is a middiastolic murmur at apex. An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm. Chest x-ray shows straightening of left heart border, elevation of left mainstem bronchus, second density behind the heart. Echocardiogram: Severe MS with marked dilation of left atrium with mitral valve diameter 1.2 cm2. No thrombi in atrium and no calcification of mitral valve.What will be the appropriate treatment in the patient
questions.correct_answer: D. Mitral balloon valvotomy

questions.text: An 18 year old male complains of dyspnea, palpitations and swelling both feet increasing for last one year. There is past history suggestive of recurrent rheumatic fever for which he took irregular penicillin prophylaxis. On examination tapping apex beat is noted along with opening snap and mid diastolic murmur at apex increasing on expiration. You order for ECG, which finding will be present on ECG?

options.label: C
options.text: Prominent negative component of P wave in V1

questions.correct_answer: C. Prominent negative component of P wave in V1

questions.text: A 25 year old female with RHD with severe mitral regurgitation(MR) comes for routine checkup. On examination pulse is irregular with rate of 120/min, pulse deficit is 15, apex is shifted laterally. There is pan systolic murmur increasing on expiration at apex.S1 is soft and S2 is wide split. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. ECHO confirm the diagnosis of severe MR with LVEF 65%.What will be most appropriate management

options.label: B
options.text: Metoprolol and plan for mitral valve repair

questions.correct_answer: B. Metoprolol and plan for mitral valve repair

questions.text: A 42-year-old comes to the ED with c/o palpitations and fluttering in his chest. He has never had this before. He denies chest pain, light headedness, or shortness of breath. He is very anxious. He drinks alcohol four to five times a week. O/E- Respiratory rate: 32 breaths/minute; BP: 118/88 mm Hg; Pulse:128 beats/minute, irregularly irregular with positive pulse deficit. What is the likely cause of patient’s tachycardia?
questions.correct_answer: B. Atrial fibrillation

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient k/c/o RHD with mitral stenosis presented with palpitations for 2 days along with sweating. Pulse rate is 140/min, pulse deficit of 15 is present with irregular rhythm. ECG revealed atrial fibrillation. When is immediate electrical cardioversion needed in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: BP 78/50 mm Hg and chest pain

questions.correct_answer: D. BP 78/50 mm Hg and chest pain

questions.text: A 45 year old male known case of hypertension on amlodipine presented with palpitations with dyspnea. On examination-pulse rate is 180/min, irregularly irregular rhythm with pulse deficit of 20. No cardiac murmur is found.BP-120/80 mmHg. He is a smoker and takes 4-5 cups of strong coffee daily. ECG done is shown in the figure. What is the most common cause of this arrythmia?
questions.correct_answer: C. Hypertension

questions.text: In continuation with previous clinical vignette the patient is uncomfortable from palpitations but is hemodynamically stable. What is the next appropriate treatment?
questions.correct_answer: D. Metoprolol

questions.text: In previous clinical case after metoprolol , the patient’s heart rate reduces to 80 beats/minute. All symptoms resolve. The patient is placed on a regular hospital ward. The echocardiogram shows a normal heart size and shape with no significant valvular disease and no thrombi. The AF does not stop, but the rate remains controlled and there are no symptoms What is the best therapy?
questions.correct_answer: A. Aspirin

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the ED complaining of palpitations. She is anxious and her chest is uncomfortable from the rapid heart rate. She is not confused, and there is no chest pain. She is a generally healthy person, and this is the first time she has been to an ED. She drank four strong black coffee today. On examination- BP: 130/80 mm Hg; Pulse: 180 beats/minute; ECG done is shown in the figure. What is the diagnosis
questions.correct_answer: C. Supraventricular tachycardia

questions.text: In continuation with previous clinical vignette patient was diagnosed as a case of PSVT. When you are checking the ECG she complaints of dyspnea and sweating and become drowsy. You check the vitals again which shows BP as 70 mmHg systolic. Chest examination revealed basal crepts. What will you do next?
questions.correct_answer: D. DC shock

questions.text: A patient admitted in ICU for treatment of pneumonia developed ventricular tachycardia as shown in the figure. On ECG monitor duration of ventricular tachycardia episodes was less than 30 seconds.Patient’s BP is 140/90 mm Hg. Palpitations are the only symptom. What should you do?
questions.correct_answer: C. Give amiodarone.

questions.text: A 24 year old female presented with sudden onset palpitations perceived as increased heart rate. It was followed by increased urine frequency. On examination pulse rate -170/min, BP-110/70 mmHg, CVS-no murmurs heard. ECG done is shown in the figure. You made a diagnosis of Supraventricular tachycardia. Carotid massage and adenosine failed to control the heart rate. You gave IV verapamil. ECG rhythm showed ventricular tachycardia now. Which of the following underlying cause most likely led to this situation in which SVT deteriorates to VT after the use of verapamil?
questions.correct_answer: C. WPW syndrome

questions.text: A 65 year old male was admitted to the hospital a week ago for an anterior wall myocardial infarction. The patient developed hypotension and lightheadedness a few hours ago. He was treated with thrombolytics on admission. On examination- BP-90/60 mmHg, raised JVP, heart sounds muffled ,no murmurs, chest: clear to auscultation. What is the immediate step?
questions.correct_answer: C. Bolus NS

questions.text: In previous clinical case patient’s BP stays at 90/60 mm Hg and his pulse rate remains 120 beats/minute. His neck veins are increasingly distended. His lungs remain clear. ABG results show PO2 68 mm Hg on room air with respiratory alkalosis. A chest x-ray reveals a cardiac shadow slightly enlarged bilaterally. What can be done first to detect the etiology?

options.label: C
options.text: A >10 mm Hg decrease in systolic BP on inspiration

questions.correct_answer: C. A >10 mm Hg decrease in systolic BP on inspiration

questions.text: A 45 year old male presented with 5 months history of swelling of feet gradually increasing.He also complaint of abdomen distension and facial puffiness. On examination-JVP distended,pulse-90/min,pulsus paradoxus noted,BP-110/70 mmHg, chest-clear,CVS- high pitch sound in mid diastole at apex,no murmurs noted. Per abdomen-ascites detetcted. What is the most likely cause of this presentation
questions.correct_answer: A. Constrictive pericarditis

questions.text: In continuation with previous clinical vignette, patient underwent investigations. Chest x ray showed calcified pericardium as shown in the figure, ECG-low voltage complexes with ST depression and T wave inversion and ECHO showed obliteration of pericardial space. Troponin levels are normal. What will be the definitive management for the patient
questions.correct_answer: D. Pericardiectomy

questions.text: A patient recently diagnosed as case of tuberculosis comes with progressive dyspnea for 2 days. On examination pulse is 130/min, BP-80/50 mmHg, JVP-raised, heart sounds are soft. Chest revealed crepts at right infraclavicular area. You immediately start patient on IV fluids and arrange for echocardiography. What will be found on echocardiogram as the first sign of cardiac tamponade?
questions.correct_answer: B. RV compression in diastole

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman was admitted with an acute MI. She underwent angioplasty and was started on aspirin, ticagrelor, atorvastatin, metoprolol, enalapril, and nitroglycerin, and placed in the ICU. One day later patient become suddenly confused. On examination- BP: 70/40 mm Hg; P: 40 beats/minute, Cardiovascular: cannon A waves in neck, Neurological: confusion, examination incomplete secondary to confusion. Chest: clear to auscultation. What will be next appropriate step.?
questions.correct_answer: A. Atropine

questions.text: A 30 year old female presented with episodes of lightheadedness, fainting episodes and weakness for last 2-3 months and symptoms are more for last 2 days. On examination pulse rate is 42/minute, BP-80/60 mmHg, chest is clear, CVS-LVS3 is auscultated. ECG done in the emergency shows the following findings. You gave IV atropine and her heart rate increased to 60/min. How does atropine increase heart rate in bradycardia?

options.label: B
options.text: Increases the rate of IF or “Funny” sodium channels

options.label: D
options.text: Increases the velocity in Purkinje fibers

questions.correct_answer: B. Increases the rate of IF or “Funny” sodium channels

questions.text: A 50 year old male diagnosed as inferior wall MI with RVMI developed bradycardia with heart rate of 40/minute. BP- 70/40 mmHg with neck vein distension. Chest is clear on auscultation.CVS-RVS3 noted. ECG shows third degree AV block as suggested by wide QRS and QRS independent of P waves. You immediately give aspirin, started IV fluid normal saline and IV atropine. The pulse rate increases from 40 to 50 beats/minute; BP rises from 70/40 to 84/50 mm Hg. You give an addition stat dose of atropine and another bolus of NS. The pulse rate is now 55 beats/minute and BP is 86/60 mm Hg. What will you do next
questions.correct_answer: D. Transcutaneous pacemaker

questions.text: A 75 year old female presented with episodes of fainting off and on for last one month. She also c/o fatigue and weakness .At times she also feels palpitations. There is no significant past medical history. She is not taking any medications. On examination pulse-42/min, BP-88/60 mmHg, chest is clear on auscultation. On CVS examination-Intermittent cannon a waves seen just after S1.There is mid diastolic murmur at apex noted. ECG is taken and shown in the figure. What is the mechanism of the cannon A wave?

options.label: A
options.text: Atrial systole against a closed tricuspid valve

options.label: B
options.text: Shunt through a patent foramen ovale

options.label: D
options.text: Back pressure from the ventricle when the mitral valve opens

questions.correct_answer: A. Atrial systole against a closed tricuspid valve

questions.text: A 45 year old male chronic smoker presented with epigastric pain for last 3-4 hours along with weakness,vomiting and sweating. On examination pulse rate – 50/min, BP-90/60 mmHg. ECG done in emergency is shown in the figure. Troponin levels are elevated. Which wall of the heart is most likely to have infarcted in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: B. Inferior

questions.text: A 65 year old male with past h/o CAD presented with chest pain for 6 hours. He is not regular with medicines. He is still smoking 10 cigarettes/day. On examination pulse is 35/min, BP-110/70 mmHg. CVS/chest examination-normal. ECG done is shown in the figure. What coronary vessel led to AV block in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Right coronary

questions.text: A 24 year old female presented with c/o chest pain and palpitations off and on for last one year. Otherwise she generally feels well. BP: 125/82 mm Hg; P: 75 beats/minute. A mid to late systolic click sound is heard. There is a late systolic murmur best heard at the apex which increased on standing and Valsalva maneuver. What is the likely cause of this murmur?
questions.correct_answer: D. Mitral valve prolapse

questions.text: A 60 year old type 2 diabetes mellitus patient presented with palpitations. On examination apex was diffuse, pulsus alternans +, soft S1, pansystolic murmur at apex noted which increased on expiration. When the patient is lying on a table and you lift the patient’s legs in the air, the murmur increases in intensity. What is the mechanism?
questions.correct_answer: A. Increasing venous return

questions.text: A 20 year old male presented with dyspnea on normal activities. He is a k/c/o RHD for last 5 years and is receiving penicillin prophylaxis. On examination pansystolic murmur is heard at apex with soft S1 and LV S3 present. Echocardiography shows LVEF 65% with regurgitant fraction of 50 ml/beat. What is the best medical management of the MR?

options.label: B
options.text: Use endocarditis prophylaxis whenever dental procedure is planned.

questions.correct_answer: D. Add lisinopril.

questions.text: A 40 year old male presented with c/o fatigue and palpitations. He gives history of recurrent sore throat followed by episodes of joint pains in childhood. On examination pulse rate 80/min, BP-140/80 mmHg, CVS-Pansystolic murmur at apex with radiation to axilla noted. The murmur was best heard in lateral decubitus position and better heard in expiration. What will be the effect on handgrip as an ausculatory maneuver on this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: It decreases venous return, softening the murmur.

options.label: B
options.text: It increases venous return, improving or softening the murmur.

options.label: C
options.text: It increases afterload, worsening the murmur.

options.label: D
options.text: Handgrip has no effect on regurgitant lesions.

questions.correct_answer: C. It increases afterload, worsening the murmur.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female k/c/o RHD comes for a routine checkup. There is a pansystolic murmur at apex radiating to axilla and increasing on expiration. On Echocardiography LVEF is 50%. The patient has no symptoms at rest or with usual exertion. She has been fully adherent to the lisinopril which was advised to her. What is the next appropriate step?

options.label: A
options.text: No change in medicines and follow-up in 3 to 6 months.

options.label: B
options.text: Switch the ACE inhibitor to an ARB.

options.label: C
options.text: Add an ARB to the ACE inhibitor.

options.label: D
options.text: Refer the patient for surgical valve repair or replacement.

questions.correct_answer: D. Refer the patient for surgical valve repair or replacement.

questions.text: A 24 year old male complaint of dyspnea increasing over last one year. On examination he has double cardiac apex, ejection systolic murmur at Erb’s area which increases on standing and Valsalva maneuver. ECHO showed banana shaped LV cavity. There is family history of sudden cardiac death in his brother at young age. What should be the initial treatment given to the patient

options.label: A
options.text: No treatment presently needed, follow up in 6 months

questions.correct_answer: B. Beta blockers

questions.text: In continuation with clinical vignette in previous patient was started on betablocker. After one year patient developed multiple episodes of ventricular arrythmias requiring DC shock. What will be most appropriate treatment for him
questions.correct_answer: C. ICD

questions.text: A 55 year old female developed chest pain on hearing tragic death of her relative due to covid infection. In emergency ECG done showed ST elevation and raised troponin. She has no previous history of CAD. She is not taking any medicines. Coronary angiography revealed no thrombus. On echocardiography there is apex dilatation in systole. What is the likely diagnosis
questions.correct_answer: D. Tako Tsubo cardiomyopathy

questions.text: An 18 year old male comes for routine health check up. A murmur is auscultated at the second left intercostal space, close to the sternum. The murmur is crescendo-decrescendo, is present throughout systole and diastole, and peaks simultaneously with S2. It does not change with position or rotation of the head. Which of the following best describes this murmur?

options.label: A
options.text: This is a continuous murmur, most likely a venous hum commonly heard in adolescents

options.label: B
options.text: This is a continuous murmur resulting from mixed aortic valve disease-AS and AR.

options.label: C
options.text: This is a continuous murmur due to a congenital shunt, likely a patent ductus arteriosus

options.label: D
options.text: Continuous murmurs of this type can only be congenital; murmurs due to acquired arteriovenous connections are purely systolic

questions.correct_answer: C. This is a continuous murmur due to a congenital shunt, likely a patent ductus arteriosus

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer presents with dyspnea for 2-3 days. On examination pulse rate 110/minute, BP-80/60 mmHg, neck veins are distended and heart sounds are soft, no S3 or S4 and no cardiac murmur present. Apex beat is not localized. Chest X ray shows a large circumferential pericardial effusion. Which of the following echocardiographic signs is likely present?

options.label: A
options.text: Collapse of right ventricle during systole

options.label: B
options.text: Collapse of left ventricle during systole

options.label: C
options.text: Collapse of right ventricle during diastole

options.label: D
options.text: Collapse of left ventricle during diastole

questions.correct_answer: C. Collapse of right ventricle during diastole

questions.text: A 57-year-old man with a history of hypertension and elevated LDL cholesterol presents to the emergency room with the acute onset of substernal chest pressure, dyspnea, and diaphoresis. His blood pressure is 158/96 mm Hg and the heart rate is 92 beats/min. Physical examination reveals clear lung fields and no cardiac gallop or murmurs. The ECG shows sinus rhythm 0.5 mm of ST elevation in lead III, and 2 mm of ST depression in leads V1–V3. Which of the following would be diagnostically useful to plan a course of action?

options.label: A
options.text: Repeat the ECG with right-sided precordial leads

options.label: B
options.text: Repeat the ECG with V7–V9 leads

options.label: C
options.text: Await results of serum cardiac biomarkers

options.label: D
options.text: Obtain a chest computed tomography (CT) to assess for pulmonary embolism

questions.correct_answer: B. Repeat the ECG with V7–V9 leads

questions.text: A 56-year-old asymptomatic man with a history of hypertension and cigarette smoking is referred for an exercise treadmill test. After 7 minutes on the standard Bruce protocol, he is noted to have 1 mm of flat ST-segment depression in leads II, III, and aVF. He stops exercising at 9 minutes because of leg fatigue and breathlessness. The peak heart rate is 85% of the maximum predicted for his age. The ST segments return to baseline by 1 minute into recovery. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: This test is conclusive for severe stenosis of the proximal right coronary artery

options.label: B
options.text: This is likely a false-positive test

options.label: C
options.text: He should proceed directly to coronary angiography

options.label: D
options.text: The test predicts a 25% risk of cardiac events over the next 5 years, most likely the development of angina

questions.correct_answer: D. The test predicts a 25% risk of cardiac events over the next 5 years, most likely the development of angina

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman was brought urgently to the cardiac catheterization laboratory in the setting of an acute STelevation myocardial infarction. She had presented with chest pain, epigastric discomfort, and nausea. Physical examination was pertinent for diaphoresis, heart rate 52 beats/min, blood pressure 85/50 mm Hg, jugular venous distention, and slight bilateral pulmonary rales. Coronary angiography demonstrated ostial occlusion of a dominant right coronary artery, without significant left-sided coronary artery disease. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Isolated infarction of the right ventricle without other wall involvement is very common

options.label: B
options.text: ST-segment elevation in leads V1 and V2 would be expected to accompany inferior ST elevation

options.label: C
options.text: The abnormal heart rate and blood pressure are likely a consequence of vagal stimulation

options.label: D
options.text: ST-segment depression is expected in lead V4R

questions.correct_answer: C. The abnormal heart rate and blood pressure are likely a consequence of vagal stimulation

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with a history of diabetes and cigarette smoking and previously normal cardiac examination is admitted to the hospital with the new onset of shortness of breath with exertion and orthopnea. She describes having experienced pain in her anterior chest 10 days earlier that lasted several hours and has not recurred. Her blood pressure is 110/88 mm Hg, the heart rate is 102 beats/ min, and she is afebrile. Her examination reveals an elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP), bibasilar crackles, and 1+ pitting edema of both ankles. On auscultation, there is a II/VI early systolic murmur between the left sternal border and apex. The ECG reveals sinus tachycardia with inferior Q waves that were not present on a tracing 6 months earlier. The chest x-ray is consistent with pulmonary edema. She is admitted to the hospital and a transthoracic echocardiogram reveals a left ventricular ejection fraction of 60% with inferior wall hypokinesis with mitral regurgitation. A diuretic is administered. Which of the following is the next most reasonable approach in her management?

options.label: B
options.text: Nuclear stress testing to evaluate for ongoing ischemia

options.label: C
options.text: Urgent coronary angiography with planned percutaneous coronary intervention

options.label: D
options.text: Initiate long-term management with aspirin, angiotensinconverting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, and beta blocker therapies

questions.correct_answer: A. Urgent surgical consultation

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman with progressive exertional dyspnea was recently found to have bilateral hilar adenopathy on chest x-ray and first-degree atrioventricular (AV) block on her ECG. A transbronchial biopsy demonstrated noncaseating granulomas consistent with sarcoidosis and she is referred to you for assessment of cardiac involvement. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the diagnostic evaluation of cardiac sarcoidosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Left ventricular regional wall motion abnormalities in sarcoidosis are typically present in coronary distributions

options.label: B
options.text: An elevated serum angiotensin-converting enzyme level has low sensitivity, but high specificity, for the diagnosis of sarcoidosis

options.label: C
options.text: 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) uptake on cardiac positron emission tomography (PET) differentiates active cardiac sarcoidosis from inactive scar tissue

options.label: D
options.text: CMR is not useful in the assessment of clinically silent cardiac sarcoidosis

questions.correct_answer: C. 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) uptake on cardiac positron emission tomography (PET) differentiates active cardiac sarcoidosis from inactive scar tissue

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presented with dyspnea on exertion. On examination pulse is 78/min, regular, BP-110/80 mmHg. On auscultation – loud S1 is heard. There is an opening snap and mid-diastolic murmur best heard in left lateral decubitus position appreciated at the apex. There is no radiation of the murmur. Lungs are clear on auscultation. What is the most likely etiology of this valvular lesion?
questions.correct_answer: A. RHD

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department with acute shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her examination is notable for sinus tachycardia. A chest computed tomography (CT) shows subsegmental pulmonary emboli, and she is started on anticoagulation therapy. An echocardiogram is performed, which demonstrates the McConnell sign as well as mild tricuspid regurgitation. Which of the following statements is correct in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: McConnell sign refers to localized dyskinesis of the right ventricular apex

options.label: C
options.text: Most common ECG sign is ST elevation in V1-V4

questions.correct_answer: B. Kussmaul sign can be seen

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia is presented to the hospital emergency complaining of crushing substernal chest pain for last 6 hours. This is associated with sweating and breathlessness. There is tachycardia with BP-140/90 mmHg. ECG shows ST segments are >2 mm elevated in multiple anterior leads. Troponin levels are raised. Which of the following electrocardiographic findings is LEAST likely in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperacute T waves in the precordial leads

options.label: B
options.text: ST-segment depression in leads III and aVF

questions.correct_answer: C. Shortened QT interval

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents for a treadmill exercise test because of intermittent chest pain. He has a history of prior tobacco use and his father died of a myocardial infarction at age 68. His baseline ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with Q waves in the inferior leads. At 6 minutes into the Bruce protocol he develops mild anterior chest heaviness and the ECG demonstrates ST elevation in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6. Which of the following statements regarding ST-segment elevation during exercise testing is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: ST-segment elevation during exercise testing is a common finding in patients with coronary artery disease

options.label: B
options.text: ST-segment elevation in a lead that contains a pathologic Q wave at baseline indicates severe myocardial ischemia

options.label: C
options.text: The electrocardiographic leads that manifest ST-segment elevation during exercise localize the anatomic regions of ischemia

options.label: D
options.text: ST-segment elevation that develops during exercise is usually a manifestation of benign early repolarization

questions.correct_answer: C. The electrocardiographic leads that manifest ST-segment elevation during exercise localize the anatomic regions of ischemia

questions.text: A previously healthy 28-year-old man presented to the hospital because of 1 month of progressive exertional dyspnea, weakness, and weight loss. One day before hospitalization he was unable to climb one flight of stairs because of shortness of breath. On examination, he appeared fatigued with mild respiratory distress. His blood pressure was 88/60 mm Hg with pulsus paradoxus. His heart rate was 110 beats/ min and regular. The jugular veins were distended without the Kussmaul sign. Pulmonary auscultation was clear. The heart sounds were distant. There is no additional heart sound or murmur heard.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Pericardial tamponade

questions.text: A 59-year-old business executive presents because of episodes of retrosternal chest discomfort that does not radiate. It is an aching, burning sensation, occurring most frequently at night, occasionally awakening the patient shortly after he has fallen asleep. It does not occur while walking or climbing stairs. His internist prescribed nitroglycerin, which he has taken infrequently. However, it does relieve his pain, usually within 10 to 20 minutes. The most likely explanation for his chest discomfort is
questions.correct_answer: B. Esophageal reflux and spasm

questions.text: A 62-year-old previously healthy man is brought to the emergency department because of severe headache and dizziness. He has no chest pain or dyspnea or fever. He takes no medications. His blood pressure is 186/98 mm Hg; his heart rate is 56 beats/min and regular. There is neck stiffness present without any focal neurological deficit. The presenting ECG is shown in Fig. Which of the following actions is appropriate?

options.label: A
options.text: Initiate antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel

options.label: C
options.text: Initiate anti-ischemic therapy with intravenous nitroglycerin and a beta blocker

options.label: D
options.text: Obtain a head computed tomographic scan

questions.correct_answer: D. Obtain a head computed tomographic scan

questions.text: A 25-year-old asymptomatic man presents for routine physical examination. The patient is tall with unusually long limbs and pectus excavatum. There is no family history of Marfan syndrome. Joint hypermotility is present. Pulse is 80/min,BP-130/80 mmHg. Cardiac examination revealed mid systolic click at apex and late systolic murmur which increased on standing and Valsalva maneuver. You make a diagnosis of MVP due to Marfan syndrome. Which of the following is among the “major criteria” for the diagnosis of Marfan syndrome?
questions.correct_answer: D. Ectopia lentis

questions.text: A 60 year old male chronic smoker presented with gradually worsening dyspnea. There is history of nocturnal awakening due to cough and breathlessness 2-3 hours after sleep. He also complaint of swelling of feet. There is past history of coronary artery disease and hypertension.He is non compliance with medicines which includes aspirin,clopidogrel,rosuvastatin and metoprolol.On examination pulse is 100/min and its amplitude is alternating with each heart beat.JVP is raised and cardiac auscultation revealed LV S3 gallop. Which of the following statements regarding this characteristic pulse seen in patients with marked LV dysfunction is true? .

options.label: A
options.text: It is usually associated with electrical alternans of the QRS complex

options.label: B
options.text: It is less readily detected in the femoral as compared with radial arteries

options.label: C
options.text: It can be enhanced by the assumption of erect posture

options.label: D
options.text: It is uncommon for patients with pulsus alternans also to have an S3 gallop

questions.correct_answer: C. It can be enhanced by the assumption of erect posture

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to his physician with shortness of breath on exertion, peripheral edema, and arthritis of his hands. On examination, his vital signs are normal. His sclerae are icteric and his skin has a bronze pigmentation. Lung examination demonstrates rales at the bases; the carotids are of normal upstroke. The cardiac impulse is displaced laterally and there is an audible S3. His abdomen is distended, with evidence of hepatosplenomegaly and ascites. There is peripheral pitting edema. Laboratory studies reveal a serum glucose level of 225 mg/dL and a transferrin saturation of 70%. Which of the following statements about this condition is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: It is inherited as an autosomal dominant condition

options.label: B
options.text: Cardiac involvement results in a mixed dilated and restrictive cardiomyopathy

options.label: C
options.text: Ventricular hypertrophy with increased QRS voltages is the most common electrocardiographic finding

options.label: D
options.text: Mainstay of treatment is iron chelating agents

questions.correct_answer: B. Cardiac involvement results in a mixed dilated and restrictive cardiomyopathy

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents for routine evaluation. She has no significant medical history. On examination, pulse rate is 88/min,BP-110/70 mmHg. There is a systolic murmur is noted at apex along with mid systolic click. Lungs are clear on auscultation. You are suspecting it to be mitral valve prolapse. Which of the following responses to maneuvers would be suggestive of mitral valve prolapse as the cause of the murmur?

options.label: A
options.text: With isometric handgrip, the murmur starts later in systole and becomes softer

options.label: B
options.text: With standing from a supine position, the murmur begins later in systole

options.label: C
options.text: Squatting from a standing position moves the onset of the murmur earlier in systole

options.label: D
options.text: Valsalva maneuver causes the murmur to arise later in systole

questions.correct_answer: A. With isometric handgrip, the murmur starts later in systole and becomes softer

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to OPD for intermittent episodes of syncopal attacks during exercise. On examination he has Bisferiens pulse with brisk carotid upstroke. Double apical apex noted. There was a ejection systolic murmur at ERB’s area which increased on inspiration and Valsalva maneuver. ECG and ECHO was advised but unfortunately he died suddenly while jogging a few days later, and a postmortem examination was performed. A histologic section of left ventricular myocardium is shown in Figure.

options.label: A
options.text: The histologic findings are of normal myocardium subjected to chronic vigorous exercise

options.label: B
options.text: This condition is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait

options.label: C
options.text: This is a disease of plasma membrane protein synthesis

options.label: D
options.text: The greatest risk to affected patients is the development of complete heart block

questions.correct_answer: B. This condition is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents for evaluation after a syncopal episode. Her family history is notable for sudden death in an older sibling. Physical examination reveals woolly hair and palmar keratosis. Electrocardiography demonstrates T wave inversions in leads V1–V3 with epsilon wave. An ambulatory (Holter) electrocardiographic monitor captures runs of ventricular tachycardia. Echocardiography demonstrates a mildly dilated right ventricle with reduced systolic function; the left ventricle appears structurally normal. Which of the following statements is TRUE about this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The majority of patients with this disorder have an abnormality of the ryanodine receptor

options.label: B
options.text: It is a form of restrictive cardiomyopathy

options.label: C
options.text: This patient likely has a mutation in the plakoglobin gene

options.label: D
options.text: This condition is transmitted in an autosomal dominant fashion

questions.correct_answer: C. This patient likely has a mutation in the plakoglobin gene

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with multiple myeloma presents with progressive exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, and peripheral edema. On examination the blood pressure is 118/62 mm Hg without pulsus paradoxus, but there is a 25 mm Hg systolic pressure postural decline. The jugular venous pressure is 12 cm, and there is periorbital purpura, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, and prominent symmetric pitting edema to the level of the mid-thighs. His electrocardiogram is remarkable for very low limb lead voltage. Which of the following is the cause of this cardiac involvement?
questions.correct_answer: B. Amyloidosis induced restrictive cardiomyopathy

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman with recent episodes of dizziness begins to feel lightheaded while seated at church, then within seconds turns pale and slumps to the floor with a few clonic jerks. She regains consciousness 1 minute later, completely aware of where she is and asks what has happened. When an ambulance arrives, her blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg and the heart rate is 60 beats/min, What is the likely cause of her syncope
questions.correct_answer: B. High-degree atrioventricular block

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes is hospitalized because of progressive exertional dyspnea and orthopnea. Her examination is notable for an elevated jugular venous pressure to the angle of the jaw, pitting peripheral edema with warm extremities, normal blood pressure, and clear mental status. The admission chest radiograph shows cardiomegaly, small bilateral pleural effusions, and vascular engorgement. After 4 days of treatment with a loop diuretic, she appears clinically euvolemic with a JVP of 7 cm H2O. However, the serum creatinine value has risen from 1.6 mg/dL at the time of admission to 2.3 mg/dL. Which of the following statements about this patient’s condition is NOT correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Diabetes and hypertension predispose to the development of cardiorenal syndrome

options.label: B
options.text: Worsening renal function during hospitalization for acute heart failure is an important predictor of early hospital readmission and mortality

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased renal venous pressure contributes to the cardiorenal syndrome

options.label: D
options.text: A disproportionate rise in blood urea nitrogen compared with serum creatinine is a sign of renal hypoperfusion

questions.correct_answer: C. Decreased renal venous pressure contributes to the cardiorenal syndrome

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25% comes for an outpatient clinic visit complaining of dyspnea and fatigue with minimal exertion (New York Heart Association class III). His medical regimen includes lisinopril, carvedilol, eplerenone, and furosemide, as well as aspirin and atorvastatin. Resting electrocardiography reveals sinus rhythm with a QRS complex duration of 160 milliseconds and left bundle branch morphology. He is being considered for implantation of a biventricular pacemaker. Which of the following statements about cardiac resynchronization therapy is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Greater benefit if given in patients with QRS duration <130 msec.

options.label: B
options.text: A patient with right bundle branch block is as likely to respond to CRT as a patient with left bundle branch block and similar QRS duration

options.label: C
options.text: CRT improves myocardial performance without increasing myocardial oxygen consumption

questions.correct_answer: C. CRT improves myocardial performance without increasing myocardial oxygen consumption

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with peripartum cardiomyopathy, left ventricular ejection fraction 25%, and a dual chamber implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) comes to see you for a routine clinic evaluation. She is able to perform most of her daily activities without limitation, but becomes short of breath walking one flight of stairs. She is currently treated with metoprolol 50 mg daily, telmisartan 80 mg daily, furosemide 40 mg daily, and spironolactone 25 mg daily. On examination the heart rate is 84 beats/min, blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, jugular venous pressure 7 cm, the lungs are clear to auscultation, and there is no peripheral edema. The electrocardiogram shows sinus rhythm with right bundle branch block and QRS duration of 120 ms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in her heart failure management?

options.label: D
options.text: No changes to the regimen as patient is stable

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase metoprolol

questions.text: A 52-year-old businessman presents to the OPD complaining of increasing fatigue and shortness of breath. He has also recently noticed that he is more comfortable sleeping on three pillows. He denies chest discomfort or pleuritic pain. His only medications are hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily and atenolol 50 mg daily for hypertension of 10 years’ duration with good control. His past medical history includes an appendectomy. He smokes 1 2 pack of cigarettes per day. He drinks whiskey socially. There is no family history of heart disease. On examination, his heart rate is 104 beats/min, respiratory rate- 20 breaths/min, and blood pressure is 134/84 mm Hg. There are no hypertensive changes in the fundus examination. There are bibasilar rales over the lower third of the lung fields; the carotid upstrokes are normal. The apical impulse is laterally displaced. S1 and S2 are normal.S3 is present. The remainder of the examination findings are normal except for a trace of pedal edema. The chest radiograph shows left ventricular enlargement. The ECG is consistent with LV hypertrophy. The most likely cause for this man’s heart failure is
questions.correct_answer: B. Alcoholic cardiomyopathy

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with long-standing hypertension presents to the emergency department because of progressive exertional dyspnea and fatigue over the past several months. Her medications include atenolol and hydrochlorothiazide. On examination, she is an overweight woman with heart rate of 70 beats/min, respiratory rate of 20 breaths/min, and blood pressure of 170/90 mm Hg. The jugular venous pressure is 14 cm. Examination of the chest is notable for bibasilar rales. The cardiovascular examination reveals a normal S1, physiologically split S2, and S4 gallop. There is no audible murmur. The extremities demonstrate pitting edema to the midcalf bilaterally. The ECG reveals sinus rhythm with voltage criteria for left ventricular (LV) hypertrophy. The chest radiograph shows a normal cardiac silhouette with bilateral pleural effusions with mild interstitial pulmonary edema. Echocardiography demonstrates concentric LV hypertrophy. The estimated ejection fraction is 70%. Which of the following pharmacologic agents has been shown to consistently improve survival in this condition?
questions.correct_answer: D. None of the above

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with progressive exertional dyspnea, fatigue, and palpitations. He has no significant past medical history and was well until 4 weeks ago, when he developed flu-like symptoms with low-grade fever, myalgias, pharyngitis, and cough. Clinical examination is consistent with decompensated heart failure. The electrocardiogram shows first-degree atrioventricular block and T wave inversions in the anterior precordial leads. Echocardiography at the time of admission reveals normal left ventricular size, global hypokinesis with an ejection fraction of 40%, and no valve abnormalities. Viral myocarditis is suspected and lisinopril, metoprolol, and furosemide are administered. However, the patient’s symptoms rapidly progress, accompanied by frequent episodes of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia. IV amiodarone is initiated, but VT episodes continue. His blood pressure is 88/40 mm Hg, the heart rate is 115 beats/min. Echocardiogram is repeated on the third hospital day: LV contractile function is now severely decreased, with an estimated EF of 15%. Which of the following management strategies would be most appropriate?

options.label: C
options.text: Perform an endomyocardial biopsy and consult cardiac surgery regarding mechanical circulatory support

questions.correct_answer: C. Perform an endomyocardial biopsy and consult cardiac surgery regarding mechanical circulatory support

questions.text: A 72-year-old diabetic man with long-standing dilated cardiomyopathy presents for evaluation of dyspnea at rest. He has been hospitalized three times within the past year for decompensated heart failure and recently underwent a cardiopulmonary exercise test showing a peak oxygen consumption of 10 mL/kg/min during maximal effort. His past medical history is notable for prior placement of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death, and prostatectomy 1 year earlier for adenocarcinoma. For the past 6 months he has been intolerant of beta-adrenergic blockers because of hypotension. He has a supportive family, adheres to therapeutic recommendations, and does not use tobacco. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 92/78 mm Hg, resting heart rate of 106 beats/min, body mass index of 26 kg/m2 , jugular venous pressure of 10 cm H2O, clear lungs, an S3 apical gallop, and cool extremities but no evidence of hepatomegaly or ascites. Laboratory studies are notable for the following: sodium 126 mEq/L; potassium 4.6 mEq/L; blood urea nitrogen 34 mg/dL; and creatinine 2.5 mg/dL. Liver function tests and the complete blood cell count are normal. Electrocardiography shows sinus tachycardia and a QRS complex duration of 96 milliseconds. Echocardiography demonstrates a dilated left ventricle with an ejection fraction of 20%, mild mitral regurgitation, and normal right ventricular size and function. Which of the following is the most appropriate consideration for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Implantation of a left ventricular assist device

questions.correct_answer: D. Implantation of a left ventricular assist device

questions.text: A 66-year-old man with a history of diabetes and hypertension presents for evaluation of exertional dyspnea. He denies associated chest discomfort, but frequently awakens from sleep with shortness of breath. On examination, he has prominent jugular venous distention, a regular heart rhythm with an apical S4 gallop, bibasilar rales, hepatomegaly, and mild bilateral pedal edema. Electrocardiography reveals sinus rhythm at a rate of 94 beats/min without ST-segment deviations or pathologic Q waves. Echocardiography is notable for a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25% and akinesis of the anterior wall. Subsequent coronary angiography reveals severe three-vessel coronary artery disease. Which of the following statements about this patient’s ischemic cardiomyopathy is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Coronary artery bypass grafting is superior to medical therapy only if angina is present

options.label: B
options.text: In hibernating myocardium function doesn’t improve after restoration of blood supply

questions.correct_answer: C. Stunned myocardium is reversible

questions.text: A 57-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with 2 hours of severe chest pain. His initial electrocardiogram shows 3-mm ST-segment elevations in leads V1–V4. Emergency coronary angiography reveals occlusion of the proximal left anterior descending artery. The left circumflex and right coronary arteries are patent without significant obstruction. Primary percutaneous coronary intervention was done. Following coronary intervention, his physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 120/70 mm Hg and heart rate of 70 beats/min. The jugular venous pressure is not elevated. On lung auscultation, bibasilar crackles are audible without wheezes. Echocardiography reveals a reduced left ventricular ejection fraction of 34%.Brief runs of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia are noted. His current regimen includes aspirin 81 mg daily, clopidogrel 75 mg daily, atorvastatin 80 mg daily, metoprolol succinate 50 mg daily, and lisinopril 10 mg daily. Which of the following interventions prior to discharge would further reduce his mortality risk?
questions.correct_answer: C. Eplerenone

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation and nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy is admitted to the hospital with acute decompensated heart failure. Her past medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes, chronic renal insufficiency, and gout. Her admission blood pressure is 90/76 mm Hg with an irregular heart rate of 94 beats/min and her examination is notable for pulmonary and systemic congestion. Treatment is initiated with a continuous IV furosemide infusion at 10 mg/h after an intravenous bolus. However, her urine output remains low her serum creatinine increases from 1.4 mg/dL to 2.1 mg/dL over the first 48 hours of hospitalization. Short runs of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia are noted. Which of the following would be most appropriate in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Addition of dopamine 2 mcg/kg/min by continuous IV infusion

options.label: B
options.text: Addition of milrinone 0.25 mcg/kg/min by continuous IV infusion

options.label: C
options.text: Addition of sodium nitroprusside 20 mcg/min by continuous IV infusion

options.label: D
options.text: Insertion of a pulmonary artery catheter for assessment of central hemodynamics

questions.correct_answer: D. Insertion of a pulmonary artery catheter for assessment of central hemodynamics

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of hypercholesterolemia and smoking is referred to the cardiology clinic for preoperative risk assessment before an orthopedic procedure. He denies any cardiovascular symptoms and exercises regularly. His ECG is shown in Figure. On examination pulse is 72/min,BP-120/80 mmHg, chest clear, CVS-no murmur identified. Which of the following statements is NOT correct?

options.label: A
options.text: This syndrome can cause ventricular fibrillation

options.label: B
options.text: Genetic mutations in the sodium channel is the cause

options.label: C
options.text: An implantable cardioverter-defibrillator is appropriate therapy to prevent sudden death

options.label: D
options.text: Antiarrhythmic therapy with procainamide reliably prevents ventricular arrhythmias in this syndrome

questions.correct_answer: D. Antiarrhythmic therapy with procainamide reliably prevents ventricular arrhythmias in this syndrome

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with diabetes mellitus and exertional angina is found to have three-vessel coronary artery disease and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 40%. He undergoes successful coronary artery bypass grafting surgery. A rhythm strip obtained on the second postoperative day is shown in Figure. On examination pulse is irregular with pulse deficit present. In JVP- a waves are absent. Preoperative administration of each of the following therapies has been shown to prevent this dysrhythmia after cardiac surgery EXCEPT
questions.correct_answer: D. Digoxin

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman is evaluated by her cardiologist because of recently recognized paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. She has a history of hypertension, diabetes, obesity (current weight is 80 kg), and chronic kidney disease with a serum creatinine of 1.3 mg/dL. She does not have a contraindication to antithrombotic therapy. There is no valvular heart disease. Which of the following would be the most appropriate antithrombotic regimen for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Anti thrombotic not required in the patient

questions.correct_answer: C. Apixaban

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy suffers two episodes of sudden syncope during gym class while jogging and is referred for further evaluation. His paternal uncle had died suddenly during physical exercise at age 20. Laboratory evaluation includes an ECG that shows normal sinus rhythm with a normal QTc interval. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging reveals a structurally normal heart. Computed tomography angiography demonstrates normal coronary anatomy. He undergoes treadmill exercise testing, and the rhythm displayed in Figure is noted after 3 minutes of exercise.

options.label: C
options.text: Beta blocker and an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator

questions.correct_answer: C. Beta blocker and an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with nonischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, left ventricular ejection fraction 38%, New York Heart Association class III symptoms, and chronic kidney disease (creatinine = 2.8 mg/dL) presents with symptomatic paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Electrocardiography when in sinus rhythm shows a corrected QT interval of 442 milliseconds. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial oral antiarrhythmic regimen to maintain sinus rhythm in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Amiodarone

questions.text: A 53-year-old man with symptomatic atrial fibrillation presents for elective outpatient cardioversion. For the past 3 months he has been taking appropriately dosed rivaroxaban as an anticoagulant, and diltiazem for rate control. Now his heart rate is 80/min,BP-110/80 mmHg, chest is clear on auscultation. ECHO shows no evidence of atrial thrombus. Which of the following statements about external electrical cardioversion is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Administration of intravenous ibutilide before electrical cardioversion facilitates successful conversion of AF to normal sinus rhythm

options.label: B
options.text: Electrical cardioversion is most effective at terminating tachycardias that arise from enhanced automaticity

options.label: C
options.text: Repeated shocks at the same energy level increase chest wall impedance

options.label: D
options.text: Rivaroxaban can be safely discontinued 7 days after successful cardioversion if sinus rhythm is achieved

questions.correct_answer: A. Administration of intravenous ibutilide before electrical cardioversion facilitates successful conversion of AF to normal sinus rhythm

questions.text: An 80-year-old man with permanent rate-controlled atrial fibrillation, hypertension, diabetes, chronic kidney disease (serum creatinine 2.5 mg/dL), and spinal stenosis has sustained three mechanical falls over the past year, without serious injury. He has a history of occasional lower gastrointestinal bleeding without a source of blood loss identified by upper, lower, and capsule endoscopy. Of the following, which is the most appropriate method for stroke prevention in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Implantation of a left atrial appendage closure device

questions.correct_answer: C. Implantation of a left atrial appendage closure device

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with permanent atrial fibrillation takes dabigatran 150 mg twice daily for stroke prevention. She sustained trauma in a motor vehicle collision on her way to work and rapidly transported to the nearby emergency department. Upon arrival, she is unresponsive, intubated, and hypotensive. Computed tomography imaging demonstrates a small intracranial subdural hematoma and a retroperitoneal hemorrhage that requires urgent exploratory laparotomy. Which of the following is the most appropriate method to reverse anticoagulation in this patient with life-threatening bleeding in need of emergency surgery?
questions.correct_answer: C. Idarucizumab

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic man with a history of myocardial infarction presents to your office for evaluation. He is known to have a left ventricular ejection fraction of 30% with anterior wall hypokinesis. He is comfortable at rest, but reports dyspnea with simple household activities and cannot ascend a flight of stairs without stopping to catch his breath. His current medical regimen includes carvedilol 25 mg twice daily; lisinopril 20 mg daily; furosemide 40 mg daily; and spironolactone 25 mg daily. His physical examination reveals blood pressure of 90/50 mm Hg, heart rate of 70 beats/min, normal jugular venous pressure, and clear lungs to auscultation. The apical cardiac impulse is laterally displaced toward the anterior axillary line. On auscultation there is a normal S1, paradoxically split S2, an apical S3 gallop, and a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex that radiates to the axilla. There is no peripheral edema. His ECG is shown in Fig.
questions.correct_answer: C. Cardiac resynchronization and defibrillator device

questions.text: A 26-year-old construction worker comes to the emergency department with palpitations. On ECG atrial fibrillation was noted. He states that for the past few months he has had occasional episodes of palpitations, almost always on Mondays. His vital signs include heart rate of 140 beats/min, respirations of 16 breaths/min, and blood pressure of 160/95 mm Hg. is physical examination is unremarkable. While being observed in the hospital, he spontaneously reverts to normal sinus rhythm. The most likely precipitating cause is
questions.correct_answer: C. Alcohol

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with elevated low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, hypertension, and a family history of premature coronary disease presents to his physician’s office for routine evaluation. He does not have diabetes. He smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and is exploring means to quit. He also has a history of supraventricular tachycardia that has been successfully suppressed by verapamil, after not tolerating a beta blocker. He is currently taking simvastatin 20 mg, verapamil and aspirin. His blood pressure is 138/70 mm Hg. Laboratory studies include total cholesterol 250 mg/dL; high-density lipoprotein cholesterol 42 mg/dL; LDL cholesterol 166 mg dL; and triglycerides 210 mg/dL. The hepatic transaminase levels are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding lipid-altering therapy?

options.label: A
options.text: No further adjustment in medication is required

options.label: C
options.text: Replace simvastatin with high dose rosuvastatin

questions.correct_answer: C. Replace simvastatin with high dose rosuvastatin

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and hypertension sustained an inferior non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction 3 years ago. A right coronary artery drug-eluting stent was placed and he has been free of angina since. His left ventricular ejection fraction is 45% with inferior wall hypokinesis. He experiences intermittent peripheral edema, particularly after salty meals, relieved by furosemide. He has stable claudication of the right calf that develops after walking two blocks. Review of systems is notable for obstructive sleep apnea and recurrent urinary tract infections. His current medications are aspirin 81 mg daily, atorvastatin 80 mg daily, metoprolol succinate 25 mg daily, lisinopril 20 mg daily, furosemide 20 mg daily, and metformin 500 mg twice daily. The serum creatinine is 1.14 mg/dL and hemoglobin A1c is 9.4%. Which of the following would be most appropriate to prescribe to improve this patient’s glycemic control and reduce his risk of future cardiac events?
questions.correct_answer: B. Liraglutide

questions.text: A 57-year-old black businessman visits his primary physician for follow-up of dyslipidemia, for which he takes atorvastatin 10 mg daily. His blood pressure is 138/84 mm Hg. He does not smoke. He consumes three to four alcoholic beverages per week. His body mass index is 28. His predicted 10-year risk for a first atherosclerotic cardiovascular event is 12% using the ACC/AHA pooled cohort risk assessment equations. Which of the following statements is consistent with current hypertension guidelines?

options.label: D
options.text: His target blood pressure should be <130/80

questions.correct_answer: D. His target blood pressure should be <130/80

questions.text: A 70-year-old businessman presented to the emergency department (ED) with multiple episodes of anterior substernal chest discomfort over the prior 2 days, each lasting 5 to 10 minutes in duration. He has a history of hypertension, elevated low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol, and had been a regular cigarette smoker until stopping 4 months ago. He experienced a single transient ischemic attack 1 year ago. His home medications included aspirin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. The initial ECG was unremarkable, but while being evaluated in the ED he experienced another 5-minute episode of chest discomfort, during which the ECG demonstrated transient 1-mm ST depression in leads II, III, aVF, V5, and V6. The initial cardiac troponin T was 0.06 ng/mL (elevated).He received aspirin, IV unfractionated heparin, beta blocker, and high-dose (80 mg) atorvastatin therapies and suffered no further episodes of chest discomfort. On examination, the blood pressure is 116/82 mmHg, heart rate 72 beats/min, jugular venous normal, the chest is clear, cardiac examination shows an apical S4 and no murmur, the abdomen is benign, and there is no peripheral edema. Three hours after presentation, the cardiac troponin T is 0.08 ng/ mL. The serum creatinine is 1.11 mg/dL. Of the following approaches, which would be most appropriate?

options.label: D
options.text: Do not add additional antiplatelet therapy at this time

questions.correct_answer: B. Add either ticagrelor or clopidogrel

questions.text: A 60-year-old man was admitted to the hospital with an acute anterior myocardial infarction (MI). He underwent urgent cardiac catheterization and successful reperfusion was achieved after a complex coronary angioplasty with stent placement. His hospital course was complicated by rising serum creatinine and urea nitrogen levels. In addition, a purple, net-like discoloration developed on his lower extremities as shown in the figure.

options.label: A
options.text: Transient eosinophilia is often part of this syndrome

options.label: B
options.text: The urinalysis likely reveals an active sediment with cells and casts

options.label: C
options.text: A high serum complement level is likely

options.label: D
options.text: Recovery of renal function within a few days is expected

questions.correct_answer: A. Transient eosinophilia is often part of this syndrome

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with hypertension, elevated low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, chronic obstructive lung disease, and gastroesophageal reflux presents to the emergency department (ED) with 1 hour of substernal chest pressure that radiates to the left arm. He had previously been healthy with no known history of coronary disease, though he led a sedentary lifestyle with little physical activity. His medications are aspirin, lisinopril, atorvastatin, Salbutamol inhaler as needed, and omeprazole. Vital signs include a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate 92 beats/min, blood pressure 160/93 mm Hg, respirations 20 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals clear lungs to auscultation, regular heart rhythm with no murmurs or gallops, and warm extremities with no peripheral edema. The electrocardiogram shows 3 mm ST elevations in leads V1–V4. Aspirin 325 mg and ticagrelor 180 mg orally are administered and he is taken emergently to the cardiac catheterization laboratory. Which of the following interventions would be most appropriate?

options.label: A
options.text: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) of left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery

questions.correct_answer: A. Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) of left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is admitted to the coronary care unit after 14 hours of chest pain that had resolved by the time of hospital presentation. The initial ECG reveals 0.5-mm ST-segment elevations with T wave inversions and pathologic Q waves in leads II, III, and aVF. The initial cardiac examination is unremarkable. On the second day, a faint late systolic murmur is heard at the apex, and by the third day this murmur has increased to grade III/VI. The patient has mild dyspnea, and a chest radiogram shows pulmonary vascular redistribution. The most likely explanation for the murmur is
questions.correct_answer: C. Infarcted posterior papillary muscle

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman with permanent nonvalvular atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and peripheral artery disease presents to the emergency department with anterior chest pressure of two hours’ duration. Her medications include apixaban 5 mg BID, metoprolol succinate 100 mg daily, indapamide 2.5 mg daily, and atorvastatin 80 mg daily. Initial vital signs are heart rate 84 beats/min, blood pressure 149/86 mm Hg, respiratory rate 18 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. The ECG shows atrial fibrillation with a ventricular rate of 84 beats/min. There are 2 mm ST-segment depressions in leads II, III, and aVF, which are new when compared with a tracing 6 months earlier. Serum cardiac troponin-T is elevated at 1.3 ng/mL. At coronary angiography there is a 95% stenosis of the mid-right coronary artery, which is treated with a drug-eluting stent. In consideration of subsequent medications, which of the following statements about combined anticoagulant and antiplatelet therapy is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral anticoagulation therapy plus clopidogrel, without aspirin (“double therapy”) significantly reduces bleeding rates compared to “triple therapy” (anticoagulation plus aspirin and clopidogrel) in patients with a need for longterm anticoagulation who undergo percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)

options.label: B
options.text: Rivaroxaban 15 mg daily plus a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor has been shown to be as beneficial as the combination of warfarin plus dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor) for prevention of ischemic events in patients undergoing PCI

options.label: C
options.text: After an acute coronary syndrome (ACS), the addition of very low-dose rivaroxaban (2.5 or 5 mg twice daily) to aspirin plus a P2Y12 inhibitor reduces the risk of cardiovascular death, nonfatal myocardial infarction, or stroke, without increasing the bleeding risk

options.label: D
options.text: Substituting rivaroxaban 2.5 mg BID for low-dose aspirin following a recent ACS reduces the rate of cardiovascular death, but increases the bleeding risk

questions.correct_answer: A. Oral anticoagulation therapy plus clopidogrel, without aspirin (“double therapy”) significantly reduces bleeding rates compared to “triple therapy” (anticoagulation plus aspirin and clopidogrel) in patients with a need for longterm anticoagulation who undergo percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with cirrhosis and chronic stable angina presents to the cardiovascular clinic for evaluation. He describes his typical angina climbing one flight of stairs, despite beta blocker and long-acting nitrate therapies. Stress testing with nuclear perfusion imaging confirms exercise induced reversible ischemia of the anterior left ventricular wall; the left ventricular ejection fraction is 50%. Coronary angiography reveals a long occlusion of the left anterior descending artery in its mid-segment with collateral perfusion to the distal vessel from the right coronary artery. The lesion is not amenable to percutaneous intervention. You are hesitant to increase the beta blocker and nitrate dosages because his resting heart rate is 50 beats/min and the blood pressure is 102/78 mm Hg. You are planning to add ranolazine. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Ranolazine would decrease the blood pressure and heart rate further and should be avoided

options.label: B
options.text: Ranolazine does not offer incremental antianginal benefit to patients already taking beta blocker, long-acting nitrate, or calcium channel blocker therapies

options.label: C
options.text: Ranolazine increases the risk of torsades de pointes

options.label: D
options.text: Ranolazine is metabolized in the liver and it should be avoided in this patient

questions.correct_answer: D. Ranolazine is metabolized in the liver and it should be avoided in this patient

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with long-standing insulin-requiring diabetes presented to OPD 2 weeks ago for management of hypertension. His blood pressure was 160/94 mm Hg. The serum creatinine was 1.6 mg/ dL and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) was 30 mg/dL, with otherwise normal serum chemistries. A potassium-sparing diuretic (triamterene plus hydrochlorothiazide) was prescribed. When he returns 2 weeks later, the serum potassium level is 6.8 mmol/L with no significant change in BUN or creatinine level. The most likely contributing mechanism is
questions.correct_answer: A. Hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman, previously healthy except for hypertension, presents to the hospital with severe substernal chest heaviness and dyspnea for the past 2 hours. The discomfort began minutes after being told that her son was seriously injured in an automobile accident. On examination she appears diaphoretic, the blood pressure is 152/84 mm Hg, heart rate 88 beats/min, O2 saturation 96%, jugular venous pressure 8 cm, the chest is clear, cardiac examination shows no gallop or murmur, and there is no peripheral edema. The ECG shows new diffuse T-wave inversions, and the cardiac troponin T is 1.07 ng/mL (elevated). She receives aspirin, clopidogrel, intravenous unfractionated heparin, metoprolol, and atorvastatin. The chest discomfort persists despite IV nitroglycerin, and coronary angiography is undertaken. No coronary stenoses are found. Left ventriculography is performed as shown in the figure.

options.label: A
options.text: She should receive anticoagulation with warfarin for the next 4 months

options.label: B
options.text: An echocardiogram 2 months later will likely show apical akinesis

options.label: C
options.text: A coronary thrombus is the likely etiology

options.label: D
options.text: This syndrome occurs predominantly in postmenopausal women

questions.correct_answer: D. This syndrome occurs predominantly in postmenopausal women

questions.text: A 55-year-old previously healthy man is brought to the emergency department because of left-sided chest pain over the past 3 hours. Pain is sharp and radiates to trapezius. He denies shortness of breath or cough. The discomfort is less intense when he sits forward. The chest radiograph is unremarkable; the ECG is shown in Figure.

options.label: A
options.text: Fibrinolytic therapy is indicated if cardiac catheterization is not immediately available

options.label: B
options.text: Nitrates will substantially relieve the chest pain

options.label: D
options.text: Glucocorticoid therapy should be initiated immediately

questions.correct_answer: C. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory therapy is indicated

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of severe chest pain and dyspnea after cocaine use. His medical history is notable for several years of intermittent cocaine use, alcohol abuse, and cigarette smoking. He has no other known cardiac risk factors. Which of the following statements about cocaine use and the cardiovascular system is NOT true?

options.label: A
options.text: Cocaine use increases the risk of myocardial infarction (MI) 24-fold in individuals otherwise at low risk for MI

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of MI after cocaine is related to the amount ingested and the frequency of its use

options.label: C
options.text: Left ventricular systolic dysfunction can occur both acutely and after long-term cocaine use

options.label: D
options.text: Mechanisms of cocaine-related myocardial ischemia and infarction include coronary arterial vasoconstriction and enhanced platelet aggregation.

questions.correct_answer: B. The risk of MI after cocaine is related to the amount ingested and the frequency of its use

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with recurrent syncope. In recent months she has noted a 10 kg unintentional weight loss, malaise, and diffuse arthralgias. She denies dyspnea, palpitations, or chest pain. Clubbing is present and early diastolic low pitch sound is heard on auscultation. A two-dimensional echocardiogram shows a pedunculated mass in right atria. Which of the following statements is TRUE about this patient’s condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The abnormality in the right atrium is most likely a thrombus

options.label: B
options.text: This lesion is more likely to develop in the right atrium than the left atrium

options.label: C
options.text: Embolism from this lesion is common

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of fever would be indicative of active infection

questions.correct_answer: C. Embolism from this lesion is common

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman underwent mitral valve replacement with a mechanical prosthesis. She was maintained on warfarin therapy and was documented to have adequate anticoagulation. Six months after the operation she had recurrent transient ischemic attacks and gives history of fever. Transthoracic echocardiography proved unrevealing. Which of the following statements is NOT correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Early infective endocarditis develops within 2 months of prosthesis placement surgery

options.label: B
options.text: Streptococcus viridans is the most likely organism to be cultured in this setting

options.label: D
options.text: Transesophageal echocardiography is more sensitive than transthoracic studies for establishing infective endocarditis diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Streptococcus viridans is the most likely organism to be cultured in this setting

questions.text: An 84-year-old woman comes for an office visit because of progressive exertional dyspnea. Evaluation, including echocardiography, reveals severe calcific aortic stenosis with normal left ventricular contractile function, moderate LV hypertrophy, and no significant mitral valve disease. Coronary angiography 2 years ago showed no coronary artery disease. Her review of systems is notable for chronic obstructive lung disease, hypertension, diabetes, and moderate renal insufficiency. She is evaluated by a multidisciplinary heart team and is considered to be at high risk for surgical aortic valve replacement (AVR), but is not inoperable. Which of the following will be best treatment for the patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) will be preferred

options.label: B
options.text: Treat underlying co morbid conditions and plan for open surgical aortic valve replacement

questions.correct_answer: A. Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) will be preferred

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman with ischemic cardiomyopathy presents for percutaneous ablation of ventricular tachycardia. She tolerates the procedure well; however, a few hours after the procedure she develops hypotension and sinus tachycardia. An emergent echocardiogram reveals a large circumferential pericardial effusion with findings consistent with tamponade physiology. Each of the following statements about the pathophysiology of cardiac tamponade is correct EXCEPT

options.label: A
options.text: Cardiac tamponade occurs when the intrapericardial pressure rises to, or above, the mean right atrial and right ventricular diastolic pressures

options.label: B
options.text: In the presence of pulmonary hypertension, echocardiographic findings of right-sided chamber compression in cardiac tamponade are less notable

options.label: C
options.text: Equalization of intrapericardial and ventricular filling pressures leads to an inspiratory decrease in left ventricular stroke volume

options.label: D
options.text: Sinus bradycardia may be a manifestation of severe cardiac tamponade

questions.correct_answer: C. Equalization of intrapericardial and ventricular filling pressures leads to an inspiratory decrease in left ventricular stroke volume

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman comes to your office because of 6 months of fatigue, weight loss, and periods of tachycardia, flushing, and diarrhea. She also describes vague fullness in her neck. Examination discloses clear lungs, an irregular pulse, distended jugular veins with a prominent v wave, a holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border that intensifies with inspiration, and peripheral edema. She is afebrile. The likely cause of her illness is
questions.correct_answer: B. Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of IV drug abuse presents to the emergency department with fatigue and night sweats. Physical examination reveals a temperature of 38.4°C (101.1°F), scattered rhonchi and wheezes in the lung fields, tachycardia without heart murmurs, and needle tracks on her arms. The chest radiograph reveals several small infiltrates in the left lung field. A transthoracic echocardiogram shows vegetations on tricuspid valve leaflets. Which of the following statements about this case is NOT true?

options.label: A
options.text: Tricuspid vale is the most common site of infective endocarditis in IV drug abusers

options.label: B
options.text: Gram-negative bacilli are a prominent cause of such lesions

options.label: C
options.text: The most likely associated organism is Staphylococcus aureus

options.label: D
